block.p: Qwest Fails to Reignite Deutsche Telekom Talks A last-ditch effort by Qwest Communications International to rekindle its negotiations to be acquired by Deutsche Telekom of Germany ended as Qwest failed to persuade U S West, its previous merger partner, to go along with a Deutsche Telekom deal.

Qwest, which has never publicly acknowledged that it was in talks with the German company, said in a statement that a ''major telecommunications company has withdrawn from discussions to acquire Qwest and U S West.'' Deutsche Telekom saw no realistic way to extricate Qwest from its previous agreement to acquire U S West.
[Page C2.]

Qwest Fails to Reignite Deutsche Telekom Talks A last-ditch effort by Qwest Communications International to rekindle its negotiations to be acquired by Deutsche Telekom of Germany ended as Qwest failed to persuade U S West, its previous merger partner, to go along with a Deutsche Telekom deal.

Qwest, which has never publicly acknowledged that it was in talks with the German company, said in a statement that a ''major telecommunications company has withdrawn from discussions to acquire Qwest and U S West.'' Deutsche Telekom saw no realistic way to extricate Qwest from its previous agreement to acquire U S West.
[Page C2.]

German Banks Detail Merger Plan Declaring that the era of ''Germany Inc.'' is over, the chief executive of Deutsche Bank, Rolf-Ernst Breuer, outlined a radical plan to merge his bank with Dresdner Bank in a stock swap worth $30 billion. With $1.2 trillion in assets, the new Deutsche Bank would be second only to the forthcoming union between three of Japan's biggest banks. The planned combination would also unravel the labyrinthine cross-holdings that have for decades bound together German banks and insurance companies.

Money Laundering Plan Criticized Senator Charles E. Schumer of New York said that he planned to ''toughen up'' legislation proposed by the White House to combat money laundering. He said that the measure left penalties against offshore banks or countries to the discretion of the authorities and that an effective policy required that suspect offshore banks be automatically forbidden access to the United States banking system.

Technology Stocks Lead a Rebound Technology shares paced a strong stock-market rally as the Nasdaq composite index soared through the 5,000 mark for the first time, climbing 149.60 points, or 3.05 percent, to 5,046.86. Other major gauges also surged, with the Dow Jones industrial average gaining 154.20 points, or 1.56 percent, to 10,010.73. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index advanced 34.99 points, or 2.56 percent, to 1,401.69.

Votes Still Needed for China Accord The Clinton administration acknowledged that it does not have the votes to pass an accord granting permanent normal trading privileges to China, and a lobbying battle was shaping up for the 130 or so uncommitted House members who will decide the fate of the president's most important remaining foreign policy goal.

Heinz Earnings Edge Up 3.5% H. J. Heinz posted a 3.5 percent increase in third-quarter profit, the smallest gain in three and a half years, on falling sales of baby foods, canned tuna and pet products. In the quarter that ended on Jan. 26, profit from operations at Heinz rose to $227.2 million, or 63 cents a diluted share. Analysts had expected Heinz to earn 62 cents a share. Shares of Heinz rose 25 cents, to $34.50. The stock has fallen a third over the last 12 months.

The Man Who Would Lead the I.M.F. Just four months ago, Horst Kohler, the head of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, said he was not in the running to be managing director of the International Monetary Fund. But a call from Germany's chancellor changed that, and Mr. Kohler's candidacy has become mired in a trans-Atlantic debate over his credentials.

Direct Marketer in Deal With AG Draft Worldwide, a direct marketing agency owned by Interpublic Group, is acquiring a majority stake in AG Worldwide, the brand strategy and advertising agency owned by Peter Arnell, the iconoclastic creative executive. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. Stuart Elliott: Advertising.

Coke Plans to Tie Pay to Diversity In a move designed to counter charges that Coca-Cola has not cared enough about building a diverse work force, Douglas N. Daft, Coke's chairman and chief executive, said that compensation at the company, including his own, would be closely tied to still-unannounced diversity goals.
